# Chord: 11th in C (Shape: G)

## Brief Description
The 11th chord is an extension of the basic major or minor triad and adds the 11th note of the scale to the chord. When played in the context of a G major chord shape, the 11th in the key of C is an F note. This chord adds color and complexity to the basic major chord, providing a jazzy or soulful sound when incorporated into musical compositions.

## Notes and Intervals
- In the context of a G major shape, the C 11th chord consists of the following notes:
  - G (the root)
  - B (the major third)
  - D (the perfect fifth)
  - F (the 11th)

## Musical Flavor and Genre
The C 11th chord, played in the shape of G, has a lush and slightly dissonant quality due to the inclusion of the 11th note. It is often used in jazz, R&B, funk, and soul music to add a sophisticated and colorful flavor to chord progressions. This chord can create a sense of tension and release, adding depth and emotion to musical passages.

## Songs
Three songs that feature the C 11th chord played in the shape of G include:
1. "Chameleon" by Herbie Hancock
2. "I Wish" by Stevie Wonder
3. "Cissy Strut" by The Meters
